abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment
            establishes the Sierra Leone Health sector reconstruction
            and Development Project as a Category B project since its
            potential negative impacts are site-specific and easily
            manageable. The issues addressed mainly focus on the
            project's impact on the biophysical and socio-cultural
            environments of the Koinadugu, Kono, Moyomba, and Bombali
            districts. Possible impacts could include deforestation and
            land cover changes caused by landfill site development and
            building rehabilitation and construction, and the resulting
            loss of biodiversity and soil fertility through erosion; the
            danger open pits create to lives as causers of injury,
            receptacles for rubbish, and breeding grounds for
            mosquitoes; poor disposal of soil and paint materials
            leading to pollution; dust associated with earth preparation
            for rehabilitation works affecting air quality; loss of
            agricultural land and crop production; ineffective waste
            disposal impairing water quality, causing water
            contamination, and water-borne diseases. However, this
            report concludes that overall there are no significant
            environmental issues to be addressed apart from those
            referenced in the medical waste management plan under the
            HIV/AIDS Response Project (SHARP). The comprehensive waste
            management plan contains the following anticipated negative
            environmental impacts and their mitigations. Appropriate
            design, sites and operation of sanitary landfills, leachate
            treatment and control, and water quality testing will reduce
            the risk of drinking water contamination. High temperature
            incineration, installation of flue gas cleaning devices, air
            quality testing, and non-incineration of materials
            containing chlorine or heavy metals will prevent release of
            pollutants into the air. Provision and ensuring the routine
            use of protective clothing, staff training, and teaching
            first aid will reduce the occurrence of occupational
            hazards. Limiting access to disposal sites, fencing of
            disposal sites, separating cells for medical wastes, and
            sensitizing the public through the media, particularly
            radio, television, posters, leaflets, newspapers, etc., will
            minimize disease transmission. Furthermore, all health care
            facilities will be equipped with appropriate equipment,
            materials, and facilities for collecting, managing, and
            transporting medical waste. Incinerators will be built and
            adapted for use in health facilities. Infectious hospital
            waste will be disposed of in sanitary landfills with set precautions.
